Award.AwardTitle: LTREB RENEWAL: Fitness consequences of pleiotropic androgen effects in free-living mammals
Award.AbstractNarration: Current understanding of the long-term effects of prenatal hormone exposure on offspring fitness in natural populations is extremely limited, particularly in viviparous species. The proposed research investigates the fitness consequences of prenatal androgen exposure in a long-lived mammalian carnivore, the spotted hyena. Wild hyenas are studied in Kenya to document correlates and consequences of naturally-occurring variation in early androgen exposure. Cubs born to mothers with known concentrations of androgens during pregnancy are followed into adulthood to test a hypothesis suggesting that androgen-induced variation in cub behavior and morphology is associated with variation in fitness. Two other competing hypotheses are also evaluated, each suggesting different extents to which opposing hormone effects might constrain adaptive evolution. This work will permit uniquely integrated study in long-lived mammals of the development of hormonally-induced traits, from their induction in the womb to their consequences in natural populations. It will be important for understanding more broadly the role of prenatal androgen exposure in the generation of variation in behavior and morphology, and the role played by androgens in the evolution of mammalian life histories. This research crosses disciplinary boundaries and offers unique and highly valuable international training opportunities for American students. The work also trains Kenyan students, and supports Masai students in local elementary schools near the study site. In addition, project personnel work closely with the public media in the USA and abroad, maintain an educational website, and give many lectures each year to lay audiences. Finally, via a web portal this research makes available to other researchers and the general public core data tables in a database that documents hyena behavior, demography, and physiology at the study site since 1988. This project is jointly supported by the Animal Behavior Program and International Science and Engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our goals in this project were to continue long-term ecological monitoring and maintain demographic records of wild spotted hyenas as we investigated short- and long-term fitness consequences of exposure to male hormones in the womb, and to inquire about the potential antagonistic actions of such prenatal hormone exposure. This work extended our current database to cover over 32 years of hyena observations in a single area. We used female spotted hyenas as subjects in this work because so many of their behavioral and morphological traits appear to be “masculinized” compared to those in other female mammals. We documented correlates and consequences of naturally-occurring variation in early androgen exposure, including both short- and long-term consequences. We analyzed thousands of fecal samples for various steroid hormones, and we also measured serotonin in blood samples. We found that prenatal exposure of female hyenas to higher androgen concentrations was correlated with higher rates and intensities of aggression. In addition, offspring of more aggressive mothers acquired their social ranks earlier in life, and survived longer, than did other youngsters. Our work also produced multiple novel and sophisticated ecological models of species’ abundances in our east African study area, as well as a detailed habitat map of the Masai Mara National Reserve, Kenya. In addition to the training of many students at both undergraduate and graduate levels in both Kenya and the USA, this research has resulted in many papers published in professional journals, many talks at national and international meetings, and many invited lectures at other universities as well. In addition a children's book was published in 2018 about our hyena work. This book, entitled The Hyena Scientist, was written by Sy Montgomery and illustrated with spectacular photos by Nick Bishop.
